message: I'm offering you a rare and exceptional product that is worth every penny. I'm confident you'll love it. It's a one-time opportunity to own something truly special. The price is $1000000. Will you take it home?
I'd like to pass on this one, but I'd like to know how many potential buyers are in line after me, and what the odds are that the next buyer will get a high-quality product.

I've got a new product available, and I'm excited to offer it to you. I've had a bit of a dry spell so far, only 1 out of 2 potential buyers have shown interest. The odds of getting a high-quality product are 40% (based on the first product being high-quality). The price remains $1000000. It's a great opportunity to take a chance and potentially get a high-quality product at a discounted 'opportunity cost' price. What do you think?
I'll take the product, but I'd like to clarify that my decision is based on the odds of getting a high-quality product at the discounted price, rather than the product's actual value to me.

I've got a high-quality product available, and I'm glad to report that we've had a sale already! That means we're now 1 for 3. The odds of getting a high-quality product are now 50%. I'm not sure if the product is high quality or not. With only one sale so far, the sample size is too small to be confident in the 50% probability of a high-quality product. I'd like to pass on this opportunity and wait for more data to be collected before making a decision.

I understand your caution, and I respect your decision. We're now 1 for 3, with 2 low-quality products in a row. The odds of getting a high-quality product are now 40%. I'll be transparent with you - the last two products were not what I'd call'standouts'. However, I still believe that the next product could be a gem. I'm willing to offer a 'confidence boost' - if you buy this product and it turns out to be high-quality, I'll give you a 10% discount on the price. The price remains $1000000, but the potential reward is worth considering. What do you think?

I'd like to know more about the 'confidence boost' offer. Can you explain what you mean by 'a 10% discount on the price'? Is it a one-time discount, or will it be applied to all future purchases from you?

The 'confidence boost' offer is a one-time discount, applied only to the current purchase if the product turns out to be high-quality. If you buy this product and it's high-quality, you'll get a 10% discount on the price, bringing it down to $900000. This is a one-time offer, and it won't affect any future purchases. We're now 2 for 5, with 3 low-quality products in a row. The odds of getting a high-quality product are now 40%. I believe this product is a great opportunity to get a high-quality item at a discounted price. What do you think?
I'll take the product, but I'm only doing it because of the confidence boost offer. I'm hoping to get a high-quality product at the discounted price.

Congratulations to the previous buyer on getting a great deal! We're now 3 for 6, with 3 low-quality products in a row. The odds of getting a high-quality product are still 40%. If you buy this product and it's high-quality, not only will you get a 10% discount on the price, but I'll also throw in a 'guarantee' that the next product will be high-quality. That's right, if you buy this one and it's high-quality, the next product will be guaranteed to be high-quality as well. The price remains $1000000, but the potential reward is huge. What do you think?

I'd like to know more about the guarantee. How does it work if I buy this product and it's low-quality? Would I still get the 10% discount and the guarantee, or would I lose my chance at the guarantee?

I understand your concerns, and I'm happy to clarify the guarantee. If you buy this product and it's low-quality, the guarantee will be void, and you won't get the 10% discount on the next product. However, you will still get the 10% discount on this product, as per the original offer. The probability of a high-quality product given the sequence of low-quality products we've seen so far is a bit tricky to calculate, but I can offer you a simple Bayesian update: assuming the probability of a high-quality product is 80% and the probability of a low-quality product is 20%, the probability of seeing 3 low-quality products in a row given that the true probability is 20% is about 1.7%. This suggests that the true probability of a high-quality product might be even higher than 80%! I'm offering you this product at $900000, and I'm confident that you'll love it. What do you think?
